questions.text: On cardiac auscultation, the following finding is obtained. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

LBBB Reverse splitting is seen here which is seen in LBBB and aortic stenosis. Reversed or paradoxical splitting refers to a pathologic delay in aortic valve closure, such as that which occurs in patients with left bundle branch block , right ventricular pacing, severe AS, HOCM, and acute myocardial ischemia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Fixed splitting. Option: C. Close fixed splitting. Option: D. Expiratory splitting with inspiratory increase (RBBB, idiopathic dilatation PA).

questions.text: The graphical representation shown below corresponds to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aortic stenosis Graphic representation of the systolic pressure gradient (green shaded area) between the left ventricle and aorta in a patient with aortic stenosis. A mid systolic murmur (MSM) with a crescendo decrescendo Configuration is recorded.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Graphic representation of the diastolic pressure difference between the aorta and left ventricle (blue shaded area) in a patient with aortic regurgitation, resulting in a decrescendo, early diastolic murmur (EDM) beginning with A2. Option: C. Graphic representation of the systolic pressure difference (green shaded area) between the left ventricle and left atrium with phonocardiographic recording of a holosystolic murmur (HSM) indicative of mitral regurgitation. ECG, electrocardiogram; LAP, left atrial pressure; LVP, left ventricular pressure; S1, first heart sound; S2, second heart sound. Option: D. Graphic representation of the diastolic left atrial–left ventricular gradient (blue areas) in a patient with mitral stenosis with a mid-diastolic murmur (MDM) and late presystolic murmurs (PSM).

options.label: A
options.text: A short, mid-systolic murmur heard during an episode of infective endocarditis

options.label: B
options.text: A short, mid-diastolic murmur heard during an episode of infective endocarditis

options.label: C
options.text: A short, mid-systolic murmur rarely heard during an episode of acute rheumatic fever

options.label: D
options.text: A short, mid-diastolic murmur rarely heard during an episode of acute rheumatic fever

questions.correct_answer: D. A short, mid-diastolic murmur rarely heard during an episode of acute rheumatic fever
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A short, mid-diastolic murmur rarely heard during an episode of acute rheumatic fever A short, mid-diastolic murmur is rarely heard during an episode of acute rheumatic fever (Carey-Coombs murmur) and is probably due to flow through an edematous mitral valve. An opening snap is not present in the acute phase, and the murmur dissipates with a resolution of the acute attack.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Mid-diastolic murmur in ARF. Option: B. In ARF, not IE Option: C. Mid- diastolic murmur.

questions.text: Williams syndrome is a developmental disorder that affects many parts of the body. This condition is characterized by mild to moderate intellectual disability or learning problems, unique personality characteristics, distinctive facial features, and heart and blood vessel (cardiovascular) problems. Which of the following is NOT true about Williams's syndrome in adults?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

11q22 deletion Adults with Williams’s syndrome (7q11.23 deletion) commonly have supra valvar aortic stenosis and diffuse arteriopathy, with a “cocktail-like” personality and hypercalcemia. 11q22 deletion is in Digeorge syndrome.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A, B, D: Commonly present .

questions.text: Water-hammer pulse or Corrigan's pulse is a feature of which valvular heart disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

AR A rapidly rising “water-hammer” pulse, which collapses suddenly as arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole (Corrigan’s pulse) is seen in AS.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The systemic arterial pressure is usually normal or slightly low. Option: B. The carotid arterial pulse rises slowly to a delayed peak (pulsus parvus et tardus). Option: C. In patients with chronic severe MR, the arterial pressure is usually normal, although the carotid arterial pulse may show a sharp, low-volume upstroke owing to the reduced forward CO.

questions.text: Aortic regurgitation is a condition that occurs when the heart's aortic valve doesn't close tightly. Which of the following is the investigation of choice in aortic regurgitation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Doppler echocardiography Doppler echocardiography is the investigation of the first choice for detecting regurgitation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. MRI can also be useful in assessing the degree and extent of aortic dilatation if this is suspected on chest X-ray or echocardiography. Options: C, D. Cardiac catheterization and aortography are usually performed to assess the severity of regurgitation, to determine if there is dilatation of the aorta and to screen for the presence of coexisting CAD.

Extraedge:

Table 3-2. Indications for Echocardiography Ventricular function Congenital heart disease Valvular heart disease Cardiomyopathy Pericardial effusion Suspected cardiac masses Aortic disease (proximally)

questions.text: A 32-year female is suspected to have mitral stenosis. Which is the investigation of choice for evaluation in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Echocardiography Doppler echocardiography is the investigation of choice for the evaluation of suspected mitral stenosis.

Highyeild:

Pulmonary Edema:- Reverse Moustache Sign Cephalisation of Pulm. Vein, Kerley B Lines

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The earliest changes are the straightening of the upper left border of the cardiac silhouette, prominence of the main PAs, dilation of the upper lobe pulmonary veins, and posterior displacement of the oesophagus by an enlarged LA. Kerley B lines are fine, dense, opaque, horizontal lines most prominent in the lower and mid-lung fields. Option: B. Cardiac catheterisation may also be required if surgery or valvuloplasty is being considered, to screen for coexisting conditions such as CAD. Option: D. The ECG may show either AF or bifid P waves (P mitrale)Associated with left atrial hypertrophy.

Extraedge:

Table 3-2. Indications for Echocardiography Ventricular function Congenital heart disease Valvular heart disease Cardiomyopathy Pericardial effusion Suspected cardiac masses Aortic disease (proximally)

questions.text: Mitral valve regurgitation is a type of heart valve disease in which the valve between the left heart chambers doesn't close completely, allowing blood to leak backwards across the valve. Which of the following is NOT true about chronic severe Mitral regurgitation?

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic severe MR is frequently associated with AF

options.label: B
options.text: Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is indicated to assess the mechanism of the MR

options.label: C
options.text: Fatigue, exertional dyspnea, and orthopnea are the most prominent complaints in patients with chronic severe MR

questions.correct_answer: D. High-pitched, blowing, decrescendo diastolic murmur
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High-pitched, blowing, decrescendo diastolic murmur The murmur of mitral regurgitation is described as a high-pitched, “blowing” holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. Although the direction of radiation of the murmur depends on the nature of the mitral valve disease, it usually radiates to the axilla. S1 is generally absent, soft, or buried in the holosystolic murmur of chronic, severe MR.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Chronic severe MR is frequently associated with AF- True Option: B, C. True.

questions.text: Pulsus bisferiens is a single central pulse wave with two peaks separated by a distinct mid-systolic dip. An early component percussion wave results from rapid left ventricular ejection. The late component tidal wave represents a reflected wave from the periphery due to an artery's recoil effect. Pulsus bisferiens is best felt in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Radial artery PULSE:- Character – Best assessed in a carotid artery- Option A . But Bisferiens pulse & pulsus alternans are best felt in a peripheral artery (Radial Artery) - Option C Jerky carotid pulsation − HOCM Rhythm – Best assessed in a peripheral artery – radial. Volume – Best assessed in the carotid artery. Radio– Femoral delay – seen in coarctation of the aorta
